The liturgical calendar of the Orthodox churches counts Sep 1, 2021 through Aug 31, 2022 as the year 7530, that is, it encompasses the vast majority of human advances during the current interglacial.  For comparison, Upper and Lower Egypt were only unified about 5100 years ago, and Sumerian civilization makes its first appearance around 6100 years ago.  Those first few millennia of the so called Holocene (a misnomer which I believe will one day be relegated to the dustbin of science history along with ether and the Piltdown Man) were very slow going.  "Progress" did not really take off in a big way until the invention of hard metal tools around 5500 years ago.   Bronze weapons gave professional armies an advantage in combat over amateurs that allowed the state to monopolize violence within its territory to an unprecedented degree, and thus we get law and order and effective tax collection to a degree that was very difficult to match in the stone age.

One problem with the proposed Holocene calendar is that the Holocene itself is a myth, as everyone should be highly aware of a few millennia from now.  The term Holocene was coined by early geologists who still thought the last ice age was a one off event.  In reality, we are still in the Pleistocene (as you can easily see by looking at Greenland's ice cap), and it will probably run for another million years approximately.   How much of our cultural complexity and energy intensive technology will still be with us once we are well into the next glacial cycle remains to be seen.  For all we know, our interglacial civilizations may be but a blip in the history of our species, or a simpler, low energy civilization may continue in some areas while other areas lapse into pastoralism or even hunting & gathering.
If we ever stop using the Gregorian calendar and start using the Holocene calendar, I think we would need to come up with Roman numeral symbols for 5,000 and 10,000 to catch up with the Human era.

I do not think that the Gregorian calendar has been imposed, it is simply the one that had the greatest diffusion and that is why it is used as a vehicle calendar.
For example, in the Islamic world, China, etc. they still use their calendars, but they also use the Gregorian calendar for international affairs.
The Holocene calendar is a great idea but it should not replace the calendars of cultures (including the Western one) cultures should not be mutilated by taking away their calendars, that would be imposing the Holocene calendar.
The correct thing would be for the Holocene calendar to be a vehicular calendar and thus each culture could maintain its calendar. Without having to give up part of their cultural expressions.
Thus, Western culture would be one more, which, like the others, maintains its calendar but also uses the Holocene calendar as a vehicle calendar. Just as other cultures would and have done.
The real mistake is wanting to homogenize cultures, the right thing to do is appreciate what each culture is and create links between cultures without forcing them to lose their identity. The Holocene calendar is a great idea as a bridge between cultures, not as a substitute for calendars because they are part of cultures.

There is no real reason to do this. This won't make anything easier or more convenient as far as date keeping.  This has one purpose and one purpose only. The way we keep yearly time: month, day, year; involves lots of different elements from different religions and cultures. This video and people who want this, only want to change year 2021 to 12021 because it remove any reference to the birth of Christ 2000 years ago. This is also where the new-made up out of nowhere- BCE/CE is trying to replace the BC/AD. Everything else will stay the same. So instead of Monday, September 27, 2021, it would be Monday, September 27, 12021. Only the year we use, a number based on the birth of Christ, would be changed. The names of the days and months which come from other religions, would stay the same. If we're going to do this, then let's be honest about it. It has nothing to do with the sweet sugary language of "....a new enlightened way of viewing history....", and more about "...revising history"....

THE HUMAN ERA CALENDAR?

We disagree profoundly with the notion of replacing our current calendaring system.

1. We're old. We like traditions. When we read scientific books, they used the style of BC ("Before Christ") and AD ("Anno Domini," in the year of our Lord). As we got older, somewhere around 1980, the new style of BCE ("Before Current Era") and CE ("Current Era") was implemented in scientific publications, we think, by and for atheist scientists. This expanded to archaeology, history, and apparently has slowly permeated all things academic. Since these new labels are concurrent with the calendaring system we use, nobody notices. But the newspapers don't seem to have adopted this so much, and the politicians aren't quick to change over either, and we think traditions have value. If you asked 100 people, probably a lot of them would guess that the Holocene is a musical act with Selena Gomez.

2. We like smaller numbers. Our generation probably wouldn't have generated the Y2K glitch if we didn't enjoy saving a couple of keystrokes here and there. We don't want to tack a "1" onto the front of every year we write for the rest of our lives; we'll leave that to some future generation seven thousand years into the future and let that be their burden.

3. Just about any measuring system with a predefined origin or index value has some kind of logic to it; or it *should*. Zero degrees Fahrenheit was a cold day in a certain town in Poland, according to an account we read, and normal human body temperature was almost 100F. That's fairly logical. Zero degrees Celsius/Centigrade refers to freezing water and 100C refers to boiling water at sea level. These are important numbers to know for most of us in the same why that absolute zero is not, so Rankine and Kelvin are fine for certain scientists and the rest of us don't care and shouldn't care. On the IQ scale, 100 is average -- no one has zero, no one has 300. When we found out the credit ratings start at 300, we thought that was crazy --- but we had no input to its creation. The very-recently-discovered archaeological find just doesn't work for us when concocting a new Year Zero. Putting the index on (or probably near) Jesus' birth seems fine to us, and we really don't want to wreck the calendar ship just to make buddy-buddy with the commies. Atheists don't really want to kill us, commies don't really want to be friends, and changing the calendar or leaving it the same, is not going to change that arrangement.

4. If you want to go after the Gregorian calendar system, go for it; but, let's start with the weaker elements. Why name the days of the week after sky objects and Norse gods? Saturn-day, Sun-day, Mo(o)n-day, and then appeals to Tiw, Woden, Thor, and Frigg. And what's the deal-eo with ISO 8601, declaring that Monday is the first day of the week, when we have always started the week with Sunday? Why name the months after the Roman calendar, with Roman gods, Caesars, and wrongly-placed numbers ("September," "October," "November," and "December" are derived from the numerals for seven through ten, but they are used to denote the ninth through twelfth months. Also, dig it: the year used to start in March.)

I haven't seen any comment highlighting this, so I will: there's an error in the dating of Caesar's death, it should be 9957 HE instead of 9956 HE.

Indeed, when converting BC dates from the Gregorian to the Holocene calendar, you have to take the number of years away from 10,001 and not 10,000. So Caesar's death, in 44 BC, happened in 10,001 - 44 = 9957 HE.

I have researched this. The original idea behind the calendar was that it started with the beginning of the Holocene, our current era. So H.E. can stand for Holocene Era, or Human Era. Adding 10,000 years to the calendar may seem arbitrary, but I believe it works. It does not really change the last 2020 years. It does not really require us to change our birth years. Instead of the United States being created in 1776, it would be 11,776. It would be inclusive of all civilizations. The Western, or Christian calendar is wrong. Jesus was not born in 1 AD (CE) or even 1 BC (BCE). The current evidence shows he most likely was born between 6 BC and 4 BC. The idea for the Holocene Calendar was proposed before new technology and information became available. Ice core samples have been used to place the beginning of the Holocene 11,700 years BP, Before Present, which is a set date of 1950. So the Holocene started around 9,750 BC. So it is a little off, but there are other factors to take into consideration. The oldest "known" proto-city, Jericho, was permanently inhabited probably no early than 9500 BC. And this is the earliest proto-city found, others came much later. The evidence for the Neolithic Revolution, true agriculture did not begin until after 10,000 BC. The same with domestication of animals, except for dogs. There is some scholars that believe that domestication of rice and the pig were earlier than 10,000 BC, but there is no physical evidence. It is hypothesized that it could have occurred earlier, but from what I have read the physical evidence for their domestication is after 10,000 BC. I feel that adding 10,000 years to the calendar would put it close to the beginning of the Holocene, before any true cities were formed, or even proto-cities, and before true agriculture began. I feel it gives us a little leeway if we find older evidence, but of course we could eventually find something older. It would, at least based on what we currently know, include all of human civilization, from farming and permanent settlements to today.

Ancient Asians (e.g three kingdoms era) eating chili pepper = 1.300 years apart, bad anachronism - scientific omission (chili not native to old world, only introduced to the world by European explorers)
Julius Caesar meeting real Egyptian Pharaoh = 300 years apart, bad anachronism.
William Wallace wearing kilt = 300 years apart, bad anachronism.
Ancient Indonesian (e.g. Srivijaya Kingdom) smoking tobacco = 300 years apart, bad anacrhonism - scientific omission (tobacco not native to old world, only introduced to the world by European explorers)
George Washington using Boeing 747 = 200 years apart, less anachronistic
Abraham Lincoln browsing the internet with Google Chrome = 150 years apart, less anachronistic

Sometimes it is not just making sense of the numbers, but a lumping history & culture altogether. Kilt being Scottish tradition makes it easy to imagining ancient figures like William Wallace wearing it. Asians liking spicy food and putting extra chili on their food, and China accounting half of global chili production makes it easy to forget that chili are recent imports (15-16th Century) introduced by the Portuguese. Likewise, smoking ciggarette being almost universal Indonesian pasttime makes it easy to think that the habit is inherrited by the ancestors. Yet, the more plausible concept like Lincoln browsing Google (which eras are much closer) and George Washington riding to battle in with AR15 rifle seems like wild fiction.

But what if historians find evidence of an even earlier temple or some other advanced structure? Imagine if we reorder our calendars to celebrate the human history, but it turns out that it actually stretches a lot more farther back?
Archeaology, geology and other sciences quite often use term BP which stands for Before Present. Since present is ever changing, they decided to go for 1950 as the "0" year. It has a lot to do with radiocarbon dating and it corresponds quite closely with the time of world wide nuclear weapon testing which has left very visible marks in the chemistry of the planet. The 50s will be quite distinct in the geological record even after 2000 years. Scientifically, this makes a lot more sense to start a new calendar with a global, recognizable event than with a supposed first, big man-made structure.

Anyway, when people get to Mars, we will finally be able to start a new, clearly defined calendar that isn't shrouded in religion or myths, as well as use scientifically defined and logical units of measure.

And what happens if and when we find an even earlier building project? Re-do the calendar again? And again. I think the idea is fine, but it's application will eventually lead to even more problems. For example, just adding 10,000 years to the present calendar is not nearly good enough. It doesn't take into consideration that pesky diversion from reality that results in the "Leap Year" correction every 4 years to bring things in line with the solar year. Or the even longer period corrections that are needed. All those things would have to be considered and would, over the period of 10,000 years, change the present date quite a bit. Since any calendar exists to tell us where we are in the orbit of the planet as it corresponds to the seasons, those corrections are vital or else anyone trying to determine a date a 5 thousand years ago would get a date that would not correspond to reality.

What if we use Human Era in such a way that calendar reform will not be needed? Here is how. We call a period of 10 000 BC to 1 BC 1st decamillennium and number years in it in chronological order. So it goes from 1 to 10 000. After year 10 000 goes year 1 of the 2nd decamillennium (same as AD 1). So we can say that we live in year 2020 of the 2nd decamillennium. It's the same as saying that we live in year 12020 HE but without needing a calendar reform. It's like we count years from the beginning of each decamillennium. Which may be a smart thing to do, by the way. Who said it's a good idea to have 5 digit year numbers? This video is promoting mythology. Does it make sense to anyone that hunters and gatherers constructed the massive expanse of Gobekli Tepe temples with spears and stones? This type of construction requires organization on a massive scale that hunters and gatherers did not yet have or even early agrarian societies did not yet possess. Each of the T-formation blocks each weigh several tons. How did they move them? Each T-block was engraved with carvings of animals, some very intricate. Even scientists and specialists are being forced to consider that possible advanced civilizations existed at the same time of hunters and gatherers and may have participated in a type of technology transfer. Ultimately, what's remarkable about Gobekli Tepe is that it throws into question what we know about human history - that it may not be so linear but rather, more advanced beings inhabiting the planet at the same time as primitive beings. I don't claim to know the answer, but authoritative British narrator doesn't mask the fact that this video is ridiculous. Unsubscribing.

Suppose it’s thousands of years older. Would we be expected to continue shifting our calendars to accommodate new discoveries?


Beyond that, the choice of this specific structure as the basis for the first year seems arbitrary. If you were to time travel back to when it was built, you would probably see that the engineering and other structural and artistic decisions were based on learnings from thousands of years before that. There is no single date at which you can say, “at this point humanity began”. So if any starting date is arbitrary anyway, why complicate historical timekeeping by introducing yet another calendar now that the world is finally at a stage where we almost entirely agree on a single calendar? We have accommodations for BC or BCE or whatever you choose to call it. It’s not like people think that Egyptian civilization was not a human civilization because it happened before the start of the modern calendar. That just seems like a silly argument.

"new year zero" - in our current system there is no year/decade/century/millennium zero. If there was, then this video would have been made in year 2016, in the 20th century and 2nd millennium instead of 2017/21st/3rd, respectively. Instead, zero can be considered as a moment between -1 BC and 1 AD, when the first year/decade/century/millennium started.

I don't agree with this calendar. Everyday we make new archeological discoveries and humanity could far older than we know of today. We could even find a site older than Gobekli Tepe. For me I think the most intuitive and less subjective type of calendar should place the year 0 when that calendar was first being used. Our current, and  calendar, the gregorian calendar started in the year 1582 which means if we put our year 0 on that date we would be in the year 437 GE (Gregorian Era) and anything before that BGE (Before Gregorian Era) This way people wont have to keep changing the calendar farther back as research continues. In fact, who says that you have to have only 2 eras? Perhaps you could have the Gregorian Era (GE 0 - Present) and the previous era being the Julian era when the Julian calendar was used. (JE 0 - 1628). And just add new eras based on what was the most used calendar before the previous one.

Proposition:
Would you be interested in making videos about history outside the Mediterranean? In school I've really mostly learned about history from the middle east, to the Mediterranean, to Europe- and somewhat Eurasia. From there it has all been American-Centric history.

But I'm curious about human history in places before: "and then the white man arrived..."
I've vaguely heard of a city in southern Africa that's architecture was even centered around fractals; as well as cities where people didn't need doors because society was so safe... and I also heard that Europeans burned those cities to the ground.

My point is I don't know much at all about the histories of those nations and cities Before they were destroyed and became part of my American History classes.
I doubt a lot of people even consider the fact that there are other histories they never learn about; because nobody tells them there are.

If you could address these histories that would truly be amazing, because I can imagine how much work would go into studying them- and how great it would be if you could share this information with people who otherwise would never hear about it.

Thank you for all your hard work on videos thus far- and best of luck if you choose to take on challenges like this in the future!

"Some forty thousand years ago, at the beginning of the last phase of the Old Stone Age (called the Upper Palaeolithic), human beings began to act very differently from the way they ever had before. For some two million years they had fashioned simple stone tools, and for half a million they had controlled fire and hunted cooperatively in groups. But forty thousand years ago, as the great ice sheets that had covered the northern continents retreated by fits and starts, humans started to invent and make new things at a tremendous rate..."
-- E. W. Barber Women's Work, The First 20,000 Years
Much of the present evidence shows this change of thinking may have occurred about 100,000 years ago, mainly in cave art and other "art" artifacts. Either way, much of the evidence is educated conjecture, and the invention Barber is talking about is the "string revolution", of which there is some evidence of it being produced about forty thousand years ago.
Humans didn't just stop somewhere in present day Turkey and begin to carve stone, there had to have been a period of learning, developing the social structure to organize the tasks, and development of the tools and techniques.

When Emiliani made his proposal in 1994, there was little consensus on when the temple was built. The time period ranged from 12,700 to 10,970 years ago.

In 2013, it was officially announced that an exact year was calculated for the completion of the temple: 9701 BCE.

Would this means the Holocene calendar should be 2017+9700 (not 9701 since there is no Year 0 in the Gregorian Calendar), which equals 11717? 11717 is a far more accurate year and would make the beginning of the Holocene an exact year and not an estimate. However, this would mean it looks nothing like 2017.

I propose we either switch to 11717, or we choose another calendar with an important significance to human technological advancement. Perhaps the establishment of the first city, Jericho? Or maybe something else. I don't know.

Small quibble. Caesar was assassinated in 44 BC, meaning 44 years before 1 AD.

There's no year 0, so it went straight from 1 BC to 1 AD.

If 1 AD is 10001 HE, then 44 years earlier would be 9957, not 9956.

9956 HE would have been 45 BC.

Easy mistake to make. You have to do "10,001 - Year BC" to get the year HE.

Yes, but for the most part of our history technology and social changes evolved at a incredibly slow pace (for instance a full Chinese dynasty lasting 800 years would use the same exact farming tools during, well, 800 years) and also we have not many data from ancient times. Therefore it makes a lot of sense to have a year zero in recent times, distinguising a long period of "ancient past" where the time scale of changes is typically very slow, and a shorter period of recent history where a lot of changes happened and also we have better records. And it makes a lot of sense to start with Rome, the first civilization we may call "modern" in many senses.

Also, we have nearly two thousand years of documents, literature, poetry, science that refers to years in the Julian calendar. Are we going to render all those texts obsolete because we decide to change the arbitrary number we assign to years? Or perhaps we are going to change the numbers in the modern translation? And, what happens with culture? 1945 is in the minds of everyone as the paramount date of the liberation of Europe for instance. Are we going to dilute its importance by calling it 11945? To me this seems nearly offensive.

Greetings. This is a great idea, and it has the power to properly present the sweep of history to the entire planet.

First, let’s specify what we are actually talking about. This is the start date of human civilization. This has nothing to do with humans as a biological species. It also doesn’t matter that at some previous date, we lived in caves. To be a civilization, a society needs to make its own infrastructure (typically in a fixed location), not borrow something else. So ants, honey bees, and termites are really hive-style civilizations (anchored in the genome software, which determines major behavior categories). Being social is not what makes civilization, its building (which works a lot better if you happen to be social). When animals in a civilization are not cooperative, they are typically behaviorally decoupled in some manner that preservers the integrity of the entire civilization.

Second, this date is always understood as an approximate date. If people really find better example of significantly earlier human civilization, we’ll just use negative numbers until we can rebase the calendar to the better value (however people may never choose to update).

Thanks for listening ;)

There are several reasons why this is either pointless or a bad idea:

1. Human history gets very murky before that point so most of the calendar would be really shittily defined, whereas our current spot for year 0 is well defined. It's good to have a starting point that's... actually at a specific event instead of some vaguely defined point. And what happens if we find some even more ancient ruins and discover human civilization stretched further back? Would we keep changing the dating system because of that?

2. We already have BC so that history would still be notated with a date. It's not as if that history doesn't exist it's simply notated differently in the calendar, and the people alive then have been dead for thousands of years so it's hardly some offensive thing. I just really don't see much of a point behind doing this.

3. The current scheduling is already culturally enshrined with cultural significance, what with 2016 Jokes, "the eighties," "the twenty first century", like extremely culturally enshrined around the globe, beyond the point of being connected with Jesus, so it would just be impractical to change it up when our current system is so culturally enshrined.

4. There are so many documents, legal, historical, monuments, etc that would need to be reworked, people reading documents or works or viewing videos that originated before this time shift would be confused as all fuck, and it would be extremely impractical, costly, and take a lot of work to try and change all the necessary legal documents and historical/informational/educational works, and would continue to be an inconvenience for a rather lengthy amount of time.

5. You would never get the whole global community to agree to this so it'd be a gagglefuck. You certainly wouldn't be able to implement such a system in the US with the Republican party certain to view this as an inexcusable attack on Christianity, or other countries with strong Christian presences, and with the vast number of countries in the world a huge number of them certainly wouldn't agree to this. It would be impractical to get the global community to do this, particularly when a lot of countries already have their hands full with real issues and wouldn't want to deal with the upset caused by them needing to change all of their documents and shit.

The whole thing just seems like a really really impractical symbolic gesture with no real tangible benefits, and the only people who would actually find anything of value in this policy are people with some OCD fixation on getting a specific dating for humanity or anti-religous people who want to shit on Christianity, and neither of those things are worth the inconvenience and upset such a change would require.

I don't like setting the "start" of the calendar at the construction of Göbekli Tepe for one important reason - if it were fifty years ago, we wouldn't even be entertaining the notion, because we hadn't excavated the site yet. Calendars have to be useful for a long time, but the pace of scientific discovery of past events makes the "beginning of the Human Era" an unfixed and constantly receding target. Just look at our current standard calendar - it was theoretically supposed to target the birth of a single individual, but we know now to an absolute certainty that if that individual's life story is to be believed, it is completely impossible for the identified year 1 to be the first year of his life.

The problem you're trying to solve here is, to put it simply, that stupid people don't fundamentally grasp how quickly technology progresses in the modern world as compared to how it's developed over the total course of human history and prehistory. Changing the calendar is certainly an option for fixing that, but it seems like it would be better to ensure that everybody gets properly educated. It might not be the absolute pinnacle of "cultural sensitivity," but I find reshaping our mechanical metrics to accommodate the subjective egos of others distasteful. We've got a reasonable calendar to work from and people have an intuitive grasp of its scope, so leave it alone. If that means that significant achievements happened in 10,000 BCE...okay. Who cares? That just makes it even more awesome.

This will only make sense if we ever learn the exact year the first temple was built. In all likelihood it probably wasn't built in exactly 10,000 BC. It could've been 10,001 BC, or maybe 9,999 BC. We could be off by decades, or even a century. Though to be fair the Julio-Gregorian calendar has a similar problem (Christ was born in April of 4 BC).

The most important event in human history was the agricultural revolution, but since we don't know exactly what year that took place (and since it probably took place over hundreds of years). The second most important event in history was the Industrial revolution, but that also took place over a number of years and there's no solid consensus on when it began and when it ended.

So I would put in an argument for the third most important event in human history (unless you put Jesus and Muhammad into the equation, which I'm not going to bother with), the assassination of Franz Ferdinand. Most people know that this sparked a diplomatic crisis between Austria-Hungary and Serbia that eventually lead to WWI, but few people realize how much it changed the course of history. Almost every major geopolitical development in the last hundred years (the World Wars, the Cold War, the rise of Communism and Fascism, the division of the Ottoman Empire and thereby the destabilization of the Middle East, etc) can be traced back to that event and it's repercussions. And on top of that it effected nearly every corner of the world in some way or another.

So I would say that 1914 should be the year zero, which would make the current year 103.

I find it objectionable of those who are constantly watering down of terms history and civilization. These are very useful concepts and should not be used as synonyms for events in time and culture.

History is the study of the human past as it is described in the written documents left by human beings. Prehistory by definition occurs before written records.

Likewise the word civilization has been corrupted to mean culture. Civilization is by definition a settled literate culture with a government.

There is no such thing as prehistoric civilization or history of illiterates by oral tradition. These are both a non-sequitur.

This does not make cultures invalid or inferior who do not have a written history or the uncivilized or illiterate cultures as violent cultures as to be dismissed as inferior which seems to be the undercurrent of those people using the word history and civilization for prehistoric, nomadic or illiterate peoples. They are only prehistoric, nomadic or illiterate. They have adapted to their environment (both natural and human) successfully to a greater or lesser extent just as civilized and historical people do. The problem is that some associate violence or other inferior quality with the uncivilized and as any casual observer can see viewing civilized societies there is no correlation between being a non-violent culture and if someone is civilized or not.

Probably a better year zero would be for the start of writing which would be the start of history, again when we have written records of events. When and where that start occurred I will leave others to debate by I would venture it would be with Sumerian cuneiform sometime around 3100-2900 B.C.E.

2:15 I think it is VERY unlikely that this is the first large scale human engineering project, no matter why it was built. It is the oldest one we know about, but what are the chances that we have found the first? There may be other, older sites that have yet to be discovered, and even THEY probably wouldn't be the first. Evidence of the first large scale human engineering project most likely has not survived to modern times. It was made of material that just didn't survive this long (like wood) or was completely destroyed by time.
Most of all, this shows that people already knew HOW to make large long lasting. Most likely the first attempts to build on this scale failed, because the people did things that didn't work. This also means they were communicating well. These attempts would need to be recorded and the reasons for the failure investigated to avoid repeating mistakes.
By the time this "temple" was built humans already knew how to build it.
On top of that, why are these old archeological finds associated with religion? My nephew, at the age of 3, made an observation that blew my mind. We were looking at an old Native American site and they had these little animals made from grass that had been found in a cave. The label said they were used in religious ceremonies to help bring a successful hunt. My nephew called them "toys".
This got me to thinking. The site had been abandoned hundreds of years before Columbus as the climate changed. The people didn't all die. As the site became unproductive the people living there would have packed up and moved away.
Stone aged people do much the same things as people do today when they move house. They pack up what they want to keep and give away or throw out those things they don't want to bother taking with them.
Important religious artifacts would surely be some of the things you'd keep, but the toys your child has out grown would be left behind.
Is it so hard to imagine a man or woman taking the time to craft something just to see the delight in their child's eye when presented with the present? How much money do you spend on cool toys for your kids?

The entire point of the Gregorian Calendar is to date events from the birth of Jesus Christ, who is considered lord and savior by a plurality of humans(around half). The building of a pagan temple in Anatolia and Greco-Persian conflicts are incredibly ancient events in human history with distant, indirect impact unlike, say the end of the Roman Republic or the life of Jesus Christ, which have more direct impacts today and were both around 1 AD. This is also when history started becoming more precise- the year 1 of the Gregorian calendar gets Jesus' birth wrong only by 5 years. Can the same be said for year 1 of the Holocene calendar? There is really no benefit to this new system except for "wow civilization has existed for so long," which is not a practical advantage.

It's silly to think that humans built all the megalithic structures around the world without the wheel and with only simple, stone hand tools. As an "evil religious nut-bag" (a fairly conservative Christian) I don't really like the new calendar because the old western calendar is roughly based on the birth of Jesus Christ (who yes I believe is God, insert insults about my mother below). But since Anno Domini (AD) is now taboo phrasing, the new calendar seems to be the logical step, because Common Era (CE) is only a stop gap phasing until there is truly a secular calendar that removes any connection to a faith tradition. (However, it is ironic that this new system is based on the building of a religious structure, maybe you should it on the best estimate for the Big Bang instead.) Furthermore, it is there any reason for a 7 day week, other than the book of Genesis? If you want a truly secular calendar you'll probably need to change the week length as well. I suggest some sort of modified metric calendar like in republican France. Yet, in spite of all these helpful hints for creating the inevitable secular calendar, this unenlightened fool will stick with "in the Year of Our Lord".

Big brained intelligent thinking humans have existed for at least (conservatively) 100,000 years but we didn't get our act together until around 6,000 years ago which is when the first civilizations show up in the record. I'm against it:
While I completly agree that it would be cool but all old texts, computer programms etc. would be using a false date. All history books would needed to be upgraded, contracts would need to be rewritten and the programmers would have to fix something like the millenium bug again.

I think the current year should be bumped to 5,017 instead. First of all, five digits just feels unnecessary and cumbersome. Second, Year 0 (which there should absolutely be) would be close to the beginning of writing. It's not that I want to exaggerate the significance of writing in human development, because there were developments in many crafts and skills before the invention of writing, and indeed before the invention of agriculture. It's just that through the medium of writing, we receive much more information about our past, so it's more convenient to have Year 0 at 3000 BC (the earliest known writing was from about 3200 BC).

the gregorian calendar does not have a year zero. The year 1 BC is followed by AD 1. I disagree with the advantages of the Holocene era. If you go many years back in history it becomes easier to count backwards than forwards. We do this naturally  when we talk about pre-history. At least for me as an historian it's much easier too get an idea about when something happened when you put AD 1 where it is. All the calculations that you will make are as easy as with the holocene era, the only difference is that you use subtractions and for the last 2000 years the present system is easier, and it is in this period that let's say 97% of the  available sources for historic reasearch are, so it's with that era that is the far most important for historians. I have never heard about anybody being offended by the fact that Christ is the starting point, so that argument is not a heavy one. The Gregorian Calendar is much more suited for historical research and the Holocene era helps professional historians very little, if anything.

This is stupid. Adding 10,000 years is just arbitrary. Dating from Gobekli Tepe is problematic. It's the oldest KNOWN great human construction project. But what if we find something older? Do we change our calendar's again? We used to think Egypt was the oldest. Then it was Sumeria. More recently it was Çatal Hüyük. If we had gone to a similar calendar system decades ago, and started counting from the founding of Çatal Hüyük, we would have gone through all the problems caused by creating a new calendar system just to have a meaningless system.

The Gregorian system while not perfect works it doesn't distort our view of history like the video claims.

The main issue is that it is not accurate. Like a lot of History before 0 BCE most numbers are rounded off by a few years, decades, and even centuries. There really isn't a way today to 100% know when an event in the past occurred unless it was otherwise stated. Not only that but we put up a wall that goes against theories (my wording is a bit weird, please bare with me). In example we can say now the pyramids were built circa 10,000 years ago, but in the future scientists and historians find out that the exact date they were built was 10,289 years ago (from 2017). That would mess up this entire Human Era Calendar, costing even more money to adopt a new one.

My argument against that calendar is that it lacks accuracy, anti-theory, costly, and unnecessary.

I honestly don't think this does anything to recognize other cultures. #1 all of the past cultures that are dead, ARE DEAD. #2 if we only adopted it in America, who would even care? This is just a waste of everyone's time. I say we keep the present calendar.

I like the idea, but I feel like the calendar shouldn't start at 10,000 BC. If the calendar has a "human era," I think it would be reasonable to begin the era at the beginning of humans, not stone temples. I feel like the date was chosen for the sake of ease of transition from the Gregorian calendar, but I don't think that should be valued over accuracy. Just like you said, historical ignorance can be propagated by calendar systems, specifically the dates at which they start; one that not only starts 12,017 years ago but uses the term "human era" seems like it might cause even more historical ignorance. Humans (i.e. organisms capable of producing fertile offspring with modern humans) likely began as early as over two million years ago. You actually made an entire video on the true chronological scope of humanity, and how for nearly all of human history, we were just bands of traveling hunter-gatherers and fishermen. So should we just make this year 2,252,017 HE? Well there are three big problems with that: 1.) We don't, and can't, know exactly when the first hominid who can produce fertile offspring with modern-day humans, at least at our current level of scientific ability. 2.) Even if we pinpoint that "first human," we would eventually need to move the date further in the future, as eventually that "first hominid" won't have been able to produce fertile offspring with future humans. 3.) It is impractical to use a calendar with so many digits.
So what should we do? Well, I say just stick with the Gregorian calendar because it is what's easiest and most accurate (except Jesus of Nazareth was really born closer to 3 BC).

I love this channel, but hold up. Humans have NOT existed for millions of years. Anatomically modern humans appeared roughly 195,000 years ago. Additionally, terraforming means to make habitable by Earth-like life. Human beings did NOT terraform Earth. The claim that the Gregorian calendar system "distorts our view of history, and makes it harder to understand who we are as a species" is an opinion not backed up in this video by fact. Please, stick to science.

In the city Tărtăria, Alba County, in 1961 was discovered an important religious complex; the material showed a continuity of habitation for several thousand years. Among others, they found three sensational clay tablets, which according to the isotope carbon 14 dating were made at least 6,500 years ago.

Two of the plates are covered with pictographic writing, over a millennium older than the famous Sumerian clay tablets. At first, the scientists thought the tablets are fakes. But the isotope Carbon 14 dating has proven that these objects are at least 6,500 years old.

Moreover, in Bulgaria has also been found a 5,500 year old clay pot, which is covered with the same type of writing/ depictions.

One thing is sure: the writing found on the “Tărtăria tablets” is the first writing in the world, which we know of. Unfortunately, the signs have remained indecipherable until this day.

I personally think that both ideas (Common Era/Anno Domini and Human Era) are great, but both of them have their pros and cons.

Both calendars work around a specific event: C.E./A.D. around the birth of Jesus of Nazareth while H.E. around the construction of the first known temple. According to H.E., Jesus was born around the year 9,996 (assuming the correct year of His birth is 4 B.C.E.). Everything fine.

Personally, I agree that some events in history before the time of Jesus could be best described in H.E. (e.g. the foundation of the Roman Empire happened in 9,973). However, after the time of Jesus, events could be best described with the C.E./A.D. (e.g. instead of saying that the fall of the Western Roman Empire happened in 10,476 we could simply say that it happened in 476). In other words, we can use the H.E. for events before the time of Jesus, and during and after His time we can use the normal calendar again.

The problem with using the 'first' temple as a starting point is that until Gobekli Tepe (the temple in Turkey) was discovered, you could have made the same argument for whatever rough date was ascribed to the oldest building known at that point. If an even older building is discovered the week after you adopt the Gobekli Tepe-based one, then your new calendar is going to look just as arbitary as the old one.

Sorry, but the idea for this is dumb, because the year 0 is ultimately arbitrary, and it's sole point is as a reference for dates. All these propositions are far worse than the current calendar system we have because they result in the dates we actually use having a far smaller ratio difference then the current one, making it harder to differentiate meaningful dates. Adding the extra one to the front is just redundant information which masks the meaningful information. This is even worse considering that we don't even have exact dates for the events which these are based on. If anything, we should move year 0 forward, as the 2000 is getting annoying, and we have more recorded history in the second millennium than the first one.

No matter which zero point is chosen, it's still arbitrary. It won't impact anyone except people capable of being able to conceptualize 10,000 years. Which is almost no one. At least the current arbitrary point is based on a somewhat known date, instead of taking that someone arbitrary point and adding 10,000 (an arbitrary number I might add) to get a different , and I would argue more, arbitrary point. Most people have a hard time conceptualization anything beyond a few days. Most of the time, I only use the last two digits anyway.

People use measurement systems based on what they are comfortable with. If you guys are comfortable with this method .. hey .. go have fun. Kelvin is a great measuring system for temperatures, but I don't see it becoming popular anytime soon either.

The same is true of other measurement systems. I see no reason to use the metric system when I'm sailing, I'm perfectly capable of operating in nautical miles as I am kilometers or regular miles. I can switch from metric to nautical to imperial measurement systems when I need to.

So one day, if I find a book with the year 12,017 in it, I'll know what to do.

But, until then, I'll probably just keep using two digit years. And I don't own any calendars, so I'm not buying this one.

While I like this idea and totally understand the benefits, the main thing holding it back for me (aside from having to change all our systems) is that 0 HE doesn't really represent anything specific. While yes, it's based around the idea of the first human building, we don't exactly have a concrete date and time for when they began construction. With the current system, it's based on the supposed birth of Jesus Christ (whether you believe he existed or not), a prominent figure in the dominating religion of western society. While that may not seem like a good subjective reason to base a whole calendar system around, it's at least something specific. For the Humanity Era, it's still based on the Current Era so as to not cause confusion. Year 0 HE represents the birth of Christ... just 10,000 years earlier because around there is when we think humanity built its first solid structure, which, to me, seems arbitrary.

And I mean c'mon, if we're still having trouble with switching from AD to CE as a society there's no way this can realistically happen. Really great video though, keep up the awesome work guys!

The idea is similar to the Julian date in astronomy. It pushes the zero date a bit further back as our understanding of the history of humanity has changed. It is a danger with calendars like this: you might get a new discovery that pushes the date negative again.

From a scientific point of view, time is nothing more than bias. There is no way to truly measure time. Our best method is a clock, but a clock has no objective referent except another clock, so it is truly an immeasurable quality without objectivity.

But, if we are going to go to the trouble of making a brand new calendar, we need to mitigate the obvious flaws in our current one. Let's not duplicate error.

For instance, we can eliminate leap year if we simply accept that a day is 23 hours, 56 minutes and 4 seconds instead of 24 hours. Yes, this means that people will, at some points in our planet's orbit, be going to work at dusk and coming home in the dark.

But the internet has shown that we no longer need be constricted by concepts of day and night. We can lose a lot of outdated "traditions" of time-keeping with a new calendar.

And this one might last 200 years before our perspective changes from what it is today and we can make a new calendar then, based on some other arbitrary starting point.

Most historians don't believe that "the magic Christ exist". Most believe that Jesus was a man who tried giving his own idea on Judaism in his time. But it didn't gain much support at the time, and he wasn't probably ordered to execution by religious figures, but just by Rome.

"There is nothing particularly special about his being executed as a public nuisance under Pontius Pilate, and the fact that he was crucified (rather than stoned to death) indicates that his death was ordered by Rome and not any religious authority."

What's important to remember is that Jesus' popularity only surged when other messianic styles became completely unsustainable for the Jewish people. That's why he became popular and known 50-80 years after he is claimed to of died. The gospels were written 50-80 years after his proclaimed death. We don't even know who wrote them.

So when it became popular to write down the oral traditions associated with him, many stories became exaggerated or fabricated as a way to exalt the messenger of this only viable message. The blame for his death was shifted away from the Roman prelates who saw him as an unremarkable but problematic eccentric, and toward the Jewish authority figures who represented the old way of thinking which had led to Rome's military suppression of the region. In fact, when a friend of mine was taking RCIA classes to explore the possibility of converting to Catholicism, her teacher pointed out that within the New Testament itself Jesus becomes gradually mores supernatural and more Hellenized/less Jewish as the books become newer.

Summary: A man named Jesus or a figure like Jesus may of existed, but this magic man called Jesus did not. Praise be to logic.

The only problem with this is that we had no idea Gobekli Tepe existed until Klaus Schmidt dug it up in 1993.  So if we had to pick a year zero before that date, we would have picked something like the foundation of Uruk at 4100 BCE, or maybe Catal Huyuk around 6500.  Had we done that, then the discovery of Gobekli Tepe would have proven that those dates were arbitrary.  What if we find something EARLIER than Gobekli Tepe though?  The likelihood that this is THE first temple is small.  It's just the first we know about.  There are undoubtedly earlier ones.  Gobekli Tepe was preserved and discovered by accident.  What if we discover an older temple?  For that matter, why is a temple the definitive break?   Why not the caves at Lascaux?  Or Chevet?  There's no real first event that shows how different humans are.  It's a nice thought but when you get down to it it's really kinda silly.  Let's keep the dates the way they are.

You should most definitely do an episode on Liquid Flouride Thorium Reactors (LIFTR). They are a "new" source of nuclear energy that leaves (almost) no waste, uses almost all of the fuel that us put into it, it's incredibly efficient, and best of all; LIFTRS use Thorium, an element that is so abundant, that a rare earth mine's success is dependent on them NOT pulling too much Thorium from the ground. The longest possible half-life for a Thorium reactor product is ~30 years, much more manageable than current amounts. Due to the nature of LIFTRS, they cannot melt down, there is a salt plug that is keeping all of the material in the core, it is cooled by a fan that the reactor itself powers. If something were to go awry, the fan would lose power, causing the plug to melt, draining the core, and preventing an accident. Similarly, if the core were to overheat, the plug would melt, and the fan would not be able to freeze the plug, therefore draining the core and preventing an accident. China has already released it's plans to build LIFTRS as a Zero-Carbon energy source, and plans to use it commercially by 2030. This is a new technology, and we need to catch up.

This is a cool idea, but there are several reasons why this really doesn't make sense. First, the reasons for using the gregorian calendar has a history all its own, so wouldn't getting rid of it also be considered "ignoring a crucial part of our history"? Also, we arent ignoring those parts of history before year 0. We have B.C for a reason. every year after A.D. or C.E. is called "Common Era" it's not called "Lol this is the only era that humans have done stuff"

Also, the gregorian calender is the most accurate recording of history throughout all cultures. Most things that happen before year 0 are really all speculation by scientists. The mere fact that all this calendar does is "Add 10,000 years onto it because lol" is what makes this seem fishy. why not 10,500 years? or 17,902 years?

It seems like such a generalized speculation that we just add 10,000 years onto our calendar instead of finding the EXACT right amount of years. You'd be saying "Hey' it's 12,017!!!" but it might not be... it might actually be year 13,847 if we are starting from the VERY START of humanity. or maybe 7908... The simple truth is, we really have no idea when exactly civilization started, but the farthest, most accurate date that we definitely DO know was at the current year 0. So that's why we use the gregorian calendar.

Also good luck trying to get every computer, calendar, school system, legal statement, law, book, film, website, and literally the mindset of every person on earth to change.... still a cool idea though.

As an archeologist I find this video bullshit and totally misleading. For instant setting the starting date as 10000 BC is totally arbitrary and doesn't in fact represent human developement well. It only includes cultures in Fertile Crescent, as neolithic revolution happened in different parts of globe at different times and was a long lasting process witjout deffinite beggining and end, unlike a birth of a person, which can be set as certain year 0. Neolithic revolution cannot. Processes that resulted in agriculture in Anatolia began long before the arbitrary 10000 BC and ended long after, so our new year 0 would be a year of no event still set according to ill-calculated birth of Christ.
Also, millenia before invention of writng is not history, it's prehistory and no date before historic times is set and certain. radiocarbon dating only gives us rough estimate of a possibility of an object age, represented as Gaussian distribution. The range of σ1 (68% probability) is 60 years. There is no set date for events before introduction of calendars and writing to an area (in the Mesopothamia it would be about 3200 BC), so at least first seven milennia of so called "Human Era" would be total bullcrap.

There is not really any convincing evidence that Göbekli Tepe (which you never even named in the video) is 12,000 years old. The oldest carbon-dated material is 11,000 years old, which is much more in line with what is generally believed to be possible. It also was not built all at once but over the course of many centuries. That doesn't change the fact that it is extremely old and impressive, but it does mean it wasn't a magical alien megastructure from the Ice Age. And it means the calendar is wrong.

If we want to date the calendar from the beginning of the Holocene, then this year should be about 11,700, the accepted beginning of the epoch and around the time of the origin of the earliest pre-pottery neolithic civilizations on Earth. Note that these civilizations probably did not build lasting structures at first and existed in the Levant, not Anatolia.

This is a very weak video for this channel.

The perspective is very subjective and it relies on some uncertain appreciations as to when humanity symbolically began to develop. Putting a 1 and a 0 in front on our current calendar would only create dissent and confusion as it will blow fundamentalists out of the water and put academia in a melting pot about the exact date.

The scope of a calendar is to offer a key reference point. For Western society and the global economy as a whole, the year 0, symbolising the Birth of Christ is a cornerstone because Christianity was the main framework in which modern society developed (from the Western viewpoint) - either we like this or not.

If I endorse the usage of the Gregorian calendar - it is not because I embrace Church doctrine - but because I believe that history should be respected and understood - not taken aside.

Not only that, but between the year 12000 BCE and 0 CE there is so little archaeological and textual support compared to ~ 0 and the present year, that it would just feel like a phantom time.

We should work on better educating our youth and ourselves on understanding ancient , pre-christian cultures and trying to preserve their values and history.

Anti-dogmatism such as anti-christian sentiments should not be confused with imposing personal outlooks on the world. The world needs less dissent; and more understanding. Attempting to revolutionise the world every now and then does not help us understand ourselves; it constantly changes our definitions and further accelerates the circle of confusion in which most people live.

We don't need a new year 0 for humanity.
We need a new future goal, a target year towards we could work together in understanding what unties in essence and meaning.

This might sound trivial, but I'd enjoy this system more if we could split the centuries from the millenniums.
For example, the year 12,452 would be referred to as "Year 452 of the 12th Millenium, HE" or "452" for short.
So long as humans don't live for several centuries at a time, there wouldn't be much confusion in using the short three digit number in daily conversation, where as the millennium would be added when comparing topics covering different time periods.

Why?

Once you get into such large numbers, they become unwieldy. Moreover, our milestones become longer.
To the first point: Imagine trying to shorten the year 24,212 to flow well in current conversation. It just doesn't flow. Simply saying the year 212 in common discourse would be very convenient.

To the second point, milestones that seem very important to us now such as centuries look more trivial when getting into such higher numbers. The year 2200 seems like a good milestone. The year 14,300, less so. But a year 300 would improve that. 3,000 is a huge milestone. 13,000, while big, doesn't have as much impact. But a Year Zero would.

Okay, let’s think about this. Where I understand the idea that of changing the existing calendars to reflect the start of what some scientists may believe humans first started to build larger structures and an age near the start of technological growth. However, has those dates been definitely pinpointed; for example, if those dates have not been exactly calculated to the day or are we just arbitrarily adding ten thousand years for the sake of rounding.
Given the inaccuracy of just arbitrarily adding ten thousand years to the calendar, would theoretically eliminate the identification of BC/AD, BCE/CE. However, we must also realize that the changing from the standard model of BC/AD to BCE/CE was purely out of political correctness, and irrelevant to what anyone traditionally called those periods; thus, it wouldn’t matter what you called it those periods, it would still be a reflection of before and after a specific moment of time. Where current calendars divide those periods on a clearly defined on a specific moment, not a random date. Furthermore, even if we did change to the proposed calendar model how would we define moments that happened before year zero. The answer would likely be by giving those moments an identifier similar to that of the traditional BC/AD, thus we would find ourselves in the same predicament.
Don’t get me wrong, I personally love this channel, and fully appreciate all the work and contribution it offers our world. However, the idea proposed in this episode has astounded me by its complete absurdity to hasten me to speak out against this proposed idea, compared to my usual silence. Remember there are no stupid questions in life; just ignorant people that follow bad ideas.

WIKIPEDIA:
" Motivation
Cesare Emiliani's proposal for a calendar reform sought to solve a number of alleged problems with the current Anno Domini era, which number the years of the commonly accepted world calendar. These issues include:
The Anno Domini era is based on an erroneous estimation of the birth year of Jesus. The era places Jesus' "birth" year in 1 BC,
but modern scholars have determined that he was born in or before 4 BC.
Emiliani argues that replacing it with the approximate beginning of the
Holocene era makes sense.The "birth" of Jesus is a less universally relevant epoch event than the approximate beginning of the Holocene era.The years BC are counted down when moving from past to future, making calculation of time spans difficult.The Anno Domini era has no year zero, with 1 BC followed immediately by AD 1, complicating the calculation of timespans further.
Instead, HE places its epoch to 10,000 BC. This is a rough approximation of the start of the current geologic epoch, the Holocene (the name means entirely recent). The motivation for this is that human civilization (e.g. the first settlements, agriculture, etc.) is believed to have arisen within this time. " - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene_calendar

As much as this video contains a compelling argument for changing the date by 10,000 years I respectfully have to disagree. It has always been that the achievements of man have been respected by those who follow. The current number system is called the Arabic numerals from the great Arab mathematicians, the elements named after those who discovered the elements and numerous inventions of the past have maintained their cultural background from which they come from. The year 0 AD as the turning point is another one of those historic landmarks flagged down by those who made strong strive to science. Great scientists such as Kepler and Calvius who worked tirelessly to figure out the world's position in our solar system and their works created the foundation for the calendar we use today. I have never had the issue of re-framing history as a way to look back at ancient Greece, Egypt, Mesopotamia and other ancient cultures, just because of the date. Rather I found the year 0 as a compelling quest to understand why the calendar is what it is and who were the fore-fathers that we owe our modern calendar to.

Does anyone else notice that human ingenuity and progress is driven almost entirely on the availability of different ideas? Think about it; moving on foot, early humans could not communicate very quickly, nor to a large number of people. Trade routes and towns pop up, allowing for faster, bigger communication booms. As transportation technologies became more advanced, humans could get their ideas around the world faster, with higher accuracy and up-to-date information. Then the Telegraph, perhaps the single most important machine and concept in human history (leaving out religion) came into the picture, allowing for cheap, instantaneous communication over almost any distance. From the mid-1800s onward, human expansion and progress from technology to government to business grew more rapidly than ever before- all because we could talk to each other faster

Our calendar does not only mark different important eras in our History, but they are our apart of our collective identity.  Many different cultures around the world, including Jews, do this.  In the Western calendar, the last major change was the birth of Jesus Christ and thus we mark the day and year of his death being Year Zero.  This is a Roman (Western) tradition and we maintain it to this day.  Why?  Because it's apart our collective culture's legacy and we should respect and cherish it.

For all those saying humans have only been around for 10k-200k years, when he said millions he wasn't talking about modern people. The Australopithecus, our common ancestor, has been around for millions of years. They eventually evolved into homo habilis, homo erectus and Homo sapiens. Even though humans didn't begin agriculture and city building until only recently in our overall history, humans have been around for around 4 million years :)

I think your calendar should have placed its year zero 200,000 years ago, when the homo sapiens first began to come about. Our Paleolithic Ancestors weren't just animals; they had complex art, languages, tools, and many other impressive things. The paintings in the Pettakere Cave are worth remembering too, as are the struggle for survival that our ancestors endured.

I refuse to believe that we are the first of our kind to accomplish this. I also refuse to believe that humanity is only a few hundred thousand years old. There's just so much we don't know about our planet's history.

I know those who dislike change or like to stick to tradition will argue against it, but that just makes me want it more. The reasoning in this video speaks to me in a way. Besides, it doesn't drastically change the units in any way. It's literally just adding a freaking 1 in front of 2016, and something as simple as that spans pretty much all we know of human history in one whole set of numbers up to present day. Change is always happening in human life, science, and technology, why not embrace a simple suggestion that makes sense?

Now, I'm not claiming to be an expert in history or related fields, so if it so happens there's a better or more accurate number for example, I might lean toward that. The main idea, though, that we can have our current calendar more accurately reflect the sheer length of human history as a whole is appealing to me. Adding a 1 in front of our current year would be the easiest adjustment we could do, in my opinion.

This overstates the importance of this date convention - and seems to play silly to the fact that it's obviously not about history, but power (the power to say Jesus was such an important figure that all lives need to revolve around it).

But about its relevance: the video seems to assume a lot of people think nothing happened before 0. That's ridiculous. Besides that, the "it gives a new perspective" thing, as much as 12000 is many more years than 2000, 2000 it's a damn fucking lot. I don't get this.

Besides, this channel is super cool and everything, but its infatuation for the idea of "progress" is so blindingly misguided. Progress into what? Even only counting material achievements, this contributes to a misguided view of people as more or less "evolved". It justifies this bullshit criteria for judging societies, if only implicitly (I'm sure the narrator is not an eurocentrist - this video is very fair when it comes to that); it builds on the fantasy of non-ideological technology and material conditions. Yes, we are as a species able to do things we could not before, but our very first machinations were social and cultural structures (much more than stone and rope was needed in order to erect that year 0 temple - a network of highly organized and motivated people), and ours are completely failing us at so many levels. So it's a bit disheartening to feel the teary-eyedness with which this channel discusses "human progress".

This kind of calendar wouldn't work. The very instant that something on the foundation for which this calendar is designed around is either found to be false, or superseded by something previously unknown, the significance of, definition of, and purpose behind the creation of the calendar, stops working. This is why the modern Gregorian calendar is still used since it is fixed, and isn't built upon some assumption. This means that it can be extended to go back and forward as far as desired, and added to without fear of changing some arbitrary criteria it needs to meet in order for it's significance and meaning to remain intact

Please take into consideration the Olmec civilisation existed in what is today's Mexico and Guatemala, in the North American Continent/Sub continent. I understand the narrator is British and thus has a Eurocentric perspective; however, it is still wrong to define the aforementioned countries (or any countries down to Panama) as part of South America. It would be great if they could clarify this with an annotation. Thanks!

I largely disagree with this, and it has little to do with my religious background. Whether atheists, scientists, or cultural philosophers like it or not, this is an era that is here to stay. Whether you believe in a god or not, call it A.D. or C.E., this era and date system is perfectly fine. It is a timeline in western culture that marks the period where Rome eventually would fall, where empires crumbled in favor of new ideas and new ages of progress in a world where said empire was already stagnating to the point of no recovery. In the last 2016-17 years we have had more progress accomplished than the entirety of the ancient world from 12,000 years ago to that point in time (say what you want about the ancient Greeks supposedly discovering steam, they had no idea what to do with it beyond 'oh look, a pretty toy,' and still relied heavily on lesser metals like bronze and iron, making the point moot).

I encourage the current era system, the same way I encourage the Chinese and their year system. It's a part of Western Culture that helps define who we are. You can call it old or silly and feel as philosophical as you want when doing so, and you are free to do so; just so long as you remember this is an era where people are free to believe in something as uproariously evil as Marxist thought, where socialism is praised despite its very obvious flaws because people define it as 'free' when it isn't, and where people celebrate cultures and ideologies of an old world that represents carnage and bloodshed just because 'it isn't white/Christian/Western so it must be the bee's knees.'

How I wonder were the people of Gobekli Tepe (the site referred to at the very beginning as the first temple) able to suddenly build such large monoliths and great structures? Before this site humans have traditionally been considered only hunter gatherers not capable of any such sedentary achievements. It is only logical that in order to create the site of Gobekli Tepe there would need to have been some practice in perfecting architecture and stone-workering, but alas there is no evidence of humans building the skills necessary to create this site before it's existence.

In the work by Graham Hancock and many others it is suggested the Gobekli Tepe is actually the work of survivors of a much older human civilization. After the Ice Age ended (roughly 12,000 years ago, the exact same time that this site is dated) there was massive flooding and cataclysm as the ice sheets melted. This would have erased all evidence of advanced civilization before the flood. However it is possible that some people may have survived, and passed down their advanced knowledge to the builders of Gobekli Tepe. This would explain how these people were able to build this site seemingly out of nowhere with no practice whatsoever.

It seems frivolous to me, considering it's not actually going to be accurate anyway. If our dating methodology became so accurate that we could determine the exact year the temple was completed then I'd say it'd be worth trying to change the calendar, but if we're just switching from one wrong year to another, i don't see that as worth the effort. And no guys, this isn't going to fail because of religious people; this going to fail because even without the hassle of changing everything, simply sustaining this revision is more effort. Most people don't bother to write the "20" in "2017", no one's going to want to add a "1"; it's a basic rule of language: bits of information that don't serve to modify a statement that could be made without that additional information tend to fall out of use. For the same reason people who all live in the same area code don't write the first three digits of a phone number for eachother, no ones ever going to be referring to the 2017 from 10,000 years ago, so it's redundant to modify the notation of the year. If we changed the year, what we'd end up with is a bunch of people writing 2017 with the unspoken understanding that human history is actually at least 10,000 years older. In other words, our current system.

From a kid who is religious and also loves history, I appreciate the sentiment and recognize that its concept has merit, but I think to restructure the year system would turn its back on the very history it preports to be representative of.  The formative years from around 0 AD to now have certainly been the most influential in history and the year system we use is a marker of this.  So, to abolish this system would be to down play its importance.  The beginning date does mark the birth of jesus, but it also marks a time around when many civilizations were advancing in the form of long distance contact and technology to support this.  Also, for those around 0 AD that had the presence of mind to begin a new and powerful year marking system should be revered with the continuation of that system.  The doing away with that system would be a brood slap in the face towards some true pioneers in human history.

The only thing I don't like about changing the calendar to this is that we weren't keeping time in this way since 12000 years ago. I know it technically isn't this way with our current calendar either, but it's much closer. I like to think that we've settled (somewhat) on a way to keep track of years and we've used that ever since. Saying the year is 12016 feels like cheating.

Just like with measuring the length of a day, or the length of a year, or using 60 to divide time in, our calendar years are horribly badly done. Don't get me wrong - there were some seriously intelligent ideas that went into all of the above, but there's simply no point in trying to change all these systems. Once you change one, you might as well change another! And another! Etc. Etc.
We don't want a full revolution or a "perfect world" because we're human. I gave up on the idea of a perfect world before I was 10 because I'd learned about examples of people trying to create these perfect worlds. Some of the time they have good intentions, but they ALWAYS end in mass tragedy. We can't reach perfect.

For that first building to be a temple and be used for 2000 years, well, wouldn't it make more sense if it was something more practically useful to individuals? People coordinating on a large-scale project usually implies there's some collective need especially when you don't have a city-state making them work.

we know that it was made of giant monolithic T shaped blocks which helped to make it strong and to last a very long time, but this also implies some prior knowledge or experience working with blocks. just because no older structure still exists doesn't mean that people weren't building even longer, and the skill required to build at this scale does imply some prior experience at work. otherwise we're suggesting that the average individual with no knowledge of how to do any crafting will be able to make a masterpiece to last thousands of years on a whim. granted, there's no direct evidence for this yet, but neither is there direct evidence for this structure being the temple. The archaeologists to one covered it simply made that assumption without any real reason aside from ethnocentricity. it was simply assumed that it must be a temple because that's what the culture viewing it would use it for.

of course, being that it's on a hill, and that it's well-fortified, it might also have served a protective function. Given it's depth it might have also kept food preserved, which would have been far more important in a time period where you have to hunt for food in a region where winter can make food occasionally scarce. if they were using salt in this era then it would have been a perfect place to keep food at a uniform temperature, and in upper levels it would have actually been warm enough to keep people alive in the coldest of winters.

I wouldn't be surprised if the community that built this had made smaller scale projects prior to it for these various functional reasons and then later on decided to put it all into one big building designed to last and later on maybe also have some religious functionality added in. there's no reason for a building to have just one purpose after all.

To anybody claiming this new calendar would not favor any religion: that's not quite true. When you look at it, it's begin date is simply defined as Gregorian Calendar's 10000BC. The temple is just a justification to add 10 thousand years (we don't know the exact year it was built).

It's purpose is not to unite people of different religions, but just a thought experiment to provide a new perspective on human civilation and make it even more apparent how much progress we achieved in more recent years. In my opinion, it's an interesting concept, but there is no practical reason to adopt it as a standard mean of measuring time.

Just one little mistake: The Olmec culture is NOT from South America.

The main area the olmecs occupied where by the Gulf of Mexico, by what is now Veracuz and Tabasco. Mexico being part of North America means the Olmecs where a civilization primary from North America (or just say Mexico to avoid confusion). It's true that the culture extended even into Guatemala (Takalik Abaj), Belice, El Salvador, Honduras, and Nicaragua but that only covers part of Central America. Meaning their territory never even reached South America.

Please, I know this is a common mistake but the american continent is divided in 3 parts: Canada, USA, and Mexico are North America. From Gruatemala/Belice to Panama is Central America, and from Colombia/Venezuela onwards is South America. Thanks for reading.

I get that this would be helpful in reframing the scale of our history, but I don't think that outweighs the negatives of the HE system. First of all, the time and effort to re-date everything would be significant, even though you "only" have to add a 1 before modern events. Secondly, it seems just as arbitrary as our current system, unless we can precisely date the temple to 12,016 years ago. Having our date system start from a guesstimated date based off of our current calendar seems silly to me, and that's also assuming they don't discover any older sites. Finally, people don't like change. It would be a massive undertaking in getting people to adopt this calendar and, as such, it would be almost guaranteed to never catch on, especially when there are so few obvious advantages.

The problem with this idea if you believe the Bible is true, is that in Genesis and other books of the bible, the lineage is recorded all the way up to the birth of Jesus. And it's not just "Adam was the father of seth, who was the father of Enosh", etc. It's "Adam lived 135 years and begot a son, Seth. Seth lived 105 years and begot Enosh", etc. etc.

So when you take all of that biblical text and you add it up, it comes to around 4000 years BC when the Earth was created. Plus another 2017 years and you get an age of the Earth around 6000 years old.

People like to laugh at that, but the simple fact is that it's what's recorded in the Bible. So Christians like myself who have faith in the Bible do not accept the ages put forth in this video.

The other problematic issue is that Paul said in Romans 5 that it was through the sin of one man that death came to all people and likewise through the resurrection of Jesus that life is brought to all people. Therefore the geneology from Adam to Christ is an important one for theological reasons.

"Well you're just anti-science! anti-fact" — Not at all. But historical science like this that you can't observe and test relies heavily on hypothesis and consensus around those hypotheses. The only difference I have is that I trust first and foremost on what is written in the bible. And if a scientific hypothesis doesn't line up with what's in the bible, then something must be wrong with the hypothesis. What's more likely to be wrong? A human being? Or the Bible? Your answer to that will reveal where you're putting your faith.
