History isn't linear but it's closer to something like an exponential function as far as how advanced we are. More things happend during a year now than a 1000 years ago due to increased population, information  and enthropy. "History" is accelerating and the calendars should reflect that. I understand the message in this video, and I certainly agree that humanity is in need of a change in perspective. I'm not going to argue for or against this idea, but I will a few make statements, that can be taken however you interpret.

Our calculations of time are arbitrary. Our calculations of time are constructs we created to assist our lives. Whatever we call the current year doesn't matter: 2016 or 12016. It still means this year. I don't think that simply changing wjst we call the year would accomplish this "change in perspective" that's intended. People who know anything about ancient history have an idea about the actual timeline of humanity. Most people know that civilization existed before what we currently call 0. A change of perspective requires much more than a change to the calendar. Personally, I am ambivalent towards this idea. If it's what people want, fine. If not, that's also fine.

P.S. I'm Catholic, not that that should affect anything I just said.

There is a problem when you study History from a STEM like perspective. You have to understand that Social Sciences are based on the human on different orders, a subject that must be studied from different lenses than the ones used in the exact sciences. That being said, this is kind of ridiculous, really. We are doing exactly the same defining the year 0 here or there. Why? Because it is arbitrary. The building of what we think might have been a temple can't be described as the origin or starting point for humanity. There are several problems with this. In the first place, we don't know exactly if it "started" ten thousand years ago or nine thousand years ago, or eleven, etc. We have approximations that, let me comment, are built mostly upon the work of Social Sciences, not STEM. That means it can't be calculated very specifically, as we tend to actually look at the processes more than a mythical origin. That brings us to the second issue: We don't need a starting point from zero, to be honest. We can't, actually. Why is the first temple an origin? Why couldn't it be the "origin" of the people who made it? Why is a building the starting point, why does that represent humanity, and not other practices? Why it doesn't start in the first human burials, for example, or the creation of the first tools? And, if a building does represent the starting point of humanity... how do we know that this is actually the first one? What if we discover an older one, since many of these discoveries are fairly recent?
The third point is that humanity did not develope in one "line". We didn't built, farmed or develope science at the same time. Rome, Greece, the mesopotamian kingdoms, the Incas, Aztecs and Mayans did not develope "civilization" at the same time. They can't even be easly defined as Civilization, as all of them had different characteristics. The Incas for example never discovered or invented the wheel. Where they "less advanced" or "late"? No. They didn't need it. Their History started in another moment.
Making a new Universal Histoy starting point older than the Anno Domini is, in some aspects, good. But we need a lot more fundamentation for where that point would be.

I don't see a point in changing our 'year 0' to one just as inaccurate but 10.000 years before, specially when it doesn't change anything at all.
- It won't help people to better realize the time scales, because the people who can't figure it out today are probably the people who don't even know when the pyramids were built, or when the first humans stopped being nomads. The point being, changing a date will not make people suddenly more interested in Human history.
- It won't help people to better realize the exponential growth of technology, for the same reason. You only have to look back 100 years to realize how much technology is changing year by year. If you can't or don't want to do it now, i doubt a different 'year 0' will change that.

That being said, I think it's a good idea to change our 'year 0' to something more meaningful to all of humanity, but that has to be an exact date, with an exact meaning. There's no point in changing it if it equally wrong, specially when it brings a lot of work for no benefit at all.

Something that's been bothering me lately... we attach a scalar to technology all the time, progress is measured by things like patents, but what are we actually measuring here? How can we say how far we've progressed if we have no clue how much further we can progress in the future? We can use things like sci-fi, but most of sci-fi is already just about possible with effort - the things that aren't are considered fantasy by serious writers and used as such. Even living in space will become a relatively bland engineering challenge once we have flexible industry there.

How "sci-fi" a culture is from our current reference has nothing to do with how a society functions and where it's going, and living in a future culture will never feel sci-fi except to the previous generation. So for instance, smartphones were a complete right-angle for the most part to a fully connected society - we have them, but they aren't used for the reasons we expected. There are uses for every single technology we've gushed over that we never anticipated or if we did anticipate were misunderstood, either as too terrifying or too unlikely. So the prophecy we try to put sci-fi to work on is and has been mostly smoke and mirrors. It's 100% confirmation bias to pick out the ones that got it right and say "Hey, technology is a ramp we can go up, and sci-fi leads the way!"

Why is it that we have to be impressed by our past if we have no idea how impressive or terrible our future is going to be? It's not for humanism - I feel that we can already respect and love humanity by interacting with each other, in fact it's a much easier and solid way to keep that philosophy. It's not for progress - we make progress through need, ambition, and hard work, not by dwelling on how slowly farmers figured out how to make bronze. So why?

I love this era of history, so I loved this video.  But, I'm not sure about why this exact moment was chosen as year zero. I assume this particular historian chose the founding of Göbekli Tepe as year zero, however it seems somewhat arbitrary to me.  There are plenty of hallmarks in human history.  Why not choose the estimated date for humanity's Y-chromosomal most recent common ancestor?  Or why not choose the time that first written document was recorded?  How about when the first farms were made?  And what if we find a similiar structure to Göbekli Tepe that was founded even earlier, will we have to push the date back?

Changing the calendar would create tons of problems for the business world, where 4 digit years are hard coded into a lot of corprorate IT systems and document software. Consistency would also be a problem, as there is a metric fuck ton of sources out there, all of which would have to be altered or stay inconsistent with the new calendar. Just imagine changing every wikipedia article.

This proposal just doesn't seem worth the amount of work it produces.

"It incorporates all humans from all cultures…" -- False, unfortunately. It includes all civilized cultures. So calling it the "Human Era (HE)" is not right either. Calling it the "Civilized Era (CE)" would be better, but unfortunately CE (Common Era) is already in use.

If you truly want to include all of humanity (defined by our species) and all of our rich cultures (including the sustainable ones that we've been doing away with), you'd need to set the 0 date back to the appearance of anatomically modern humans. That would be an even more impressive scale!

Having the date as 2016 is a constant reminder of Christ, if only on an almost subliminal level.

There is no need to make our past "more impressive" if you are not impressed already, there is something wrong with your sense of scale. All cultures are not equivalent, and some matter more than others.This is demonstrated by the exclusion of the Tabernacle in the Desert after the Jews left Egypt, a central part of history, and many others that are at the least, interesting.

There btw is no year 0, at least not in the Gregorian calendar. If you list f.e. 3 BCE TO 3 CE (or 3 BC to 3 AD if you prefer) the list goes 3 BCE, 2, BCE, 1 BCE, 1 CE, 2 CE, 3 CE.

If the year 0 CE existed you would always have to add one when combining years before and after the start of the current era. So if a man is born 20 BCE and dies at 60, he dies in 40 CE in our current system, but if you want to use the year 0 CE he dies in 39 CE.
